questions.text: Scar endometriosis can occur following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endometriosis sometimes occurs in abdominal wall scars following operations on the uterus or tubes, and is known as scar endometriosis. It occurs in all of the following options.

  • It is a painful, nodular swelling near the scar
  • Cyclical pain (worsens during menstruation)
  • Confirmed by histopathology

Operations most likely to be followed by scar endometriosis:

  • Hysterotomy (Option B)
  • Classical cesarean section (Option A): Endometrial cells can implant in the abdominal wall incision during surgery.
  • Myomectomy
  • Ventrofixation
  • Following operations for a section of the fallopian tube
  • Following operations for the removal of pelvic endometriosis
  • Episiotomy (Option C): Rare but possible while implantation during vaginal delivery with endometrial contamination.

choices.text: Most common in the 3rd or 4th decade
Endometrial sarcoma is the most common malignancy associated

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common malignancy associated with endometriosis is endometrioid adenocarcinoma, not sarcoma.

  • Endometriosis occurs most commonly in the 3rd or 4th decade (Option A)
  • If a first-degree relative is affected, there is a 7-10 fold increased chance of a female having endometriosis.
  • Endometrioma/chocolate cyst is a true cyst (Option D)
  • Premenstrual spotting is seen in endometriosis (Option B)
  • Endometriosis is associated with clear cell carcinoma, endometrial ovarian cancer

questions.text: Pain in endometriosis correlates with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pain in endometriosis correlates most strongly with the depth of invasion of the lesions rather than the extent or number of sites.

  • Deep infiltrating endometriosis (DIE) is a severe form described by Koninck's group, where lesions extend ≥10 mm below the peritoneal surface.
  • These deep lesions are more strongly associated with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia.
  • In contrast, superficial or less deeply located lesions are more often linked with infertility rather than pain.

Explanation for other options:

Multiple sites (Option B): Pain in endometriosis is not directly proportional to the number of sites involved. A patient with multiple superficial lesions may be asymptomatic, while another with a single deep lesion can experience severe pain.

CA 125 (Option C): CA 125 is a nonspecific tumour marker that may be elevated in endometriosis, but its level does not correlate with the severity of pain.

Stage of disease (Option D): The clinical stage of endometriosis (based on the revised ASRM classification) does not reliably correlate with pain severity. Even patients with Stage I (minimal disease) can experience severe pain, while some with Stage IV (extensive disease) may be asymptomatic.

choices.text: Can involve the lungs and pleura
The ovary is the most common site

questions.text: All are true regarding endometriosis, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endometriotic cysts (chocolate cysts) contain thick, old, altered blood (dark brown fluid), not clear fluid.

  • Endometriosis is the occurrence of functioning endometrial tissue (glands + stroma) outside the uterine cavity.
  • Whatever the initial genesis of endometriosis, its further development depends mainly on estrogen (Option A).
  • It can occur anywhere in the body, most common site being the ovary (Option D).
  • It can also involve the lungs and pleura (Option B).
  • In endometriosis, the tarry dark brown fluid is due to the presence of blood pigments like hemosiderin, and the cul-de-sac has yellow brown fluid.

questions.text: All are used in the treatment of endometriosis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tibolone is indicated for the management of vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause and for the prevention of bone loss. It can be considered an alternative to conventional HRT where improvement in libido is desired.

Drugs used in the management of endometriosis: (Procter and Gamble Always Offers Good Deals)

  • Procter: Progesterone (First line management)
    1. Injectable progestin (DMPA and LNG-IUS) (Option A)
    2. Oral progestins (continuous administration)
  • Gamble: GnRH analogue
  • Always; Antiprogesterone-mifepristone
  • Offers: OCP (Option C)
  • Good: Gestrinone
  • Deals: Danazol (Option D)

Estrogen stimulates endometrial tissue growth and can worsen endometriosis. It is contraindicated.

Superficial peritoneal and ovarian implants may respond well to medical management, but large endometriomas and extra-pelvic endometriosis are unlikely to respond and will ultimately require surgical excision.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea. She had a history of infertility, and intraoperative findings showed as below.
What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history and given image suggest a chocolate cyst of the ovary.

Chocolate cysts of the ovary:

  • They are true cysts
  • The cysts enlarge with cyclic bleeding. The serum gets absorbed in between periods, and the content inside becomes chocolate, tarry brown.
  • Histology - Lining epithelium is columnar epithelium
  • Beneath the epithelium are large macrophages called pseudoxanthoma cells, which have brown cytoplasm due to ingested blood pigments like hemosiderin.
  • Treatment of chocolate cyst/endometrioma.
  • Laparoscopic management is the preferred management.

questions.text: Endometriosis is explained by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endometriosis is explained by all of the given theories.

Endometriosis is defined as the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity. Multiple theories have been proposed to explain its origin:

Sampson's Implantation Theory (Retrograde Menstruation Theory)

  • Most widely accepted theory.
  • Suggests that menstrual blood containing endometrial cells flows backwards through the fallopian tubes into the peritoneal cavity.
  • These viable endometrial cells implant on peritoneal surfaces and proliferate.
  • Best explains pelvic endometriosis (ovaries, pouch of Douglas).

Coelomic Metaplasia Theory (Meyer and Ivanoff)

  • Suggests that the coelomic epithelium (embryonic mesothelium) has the potential to undergo metaplastic transformation into endometrial tissue.
  • Supported by the embryologic similarity between the peritoneum and endometrium.
  • Explains endometriosis in women without menstruation, e.g., Müllerian agenesis.

Halban's Vascular or Lymphatic Dissemination Theory (Metastatic Theory)

  • Proposes that endometrial cells spread via blood or lymphatic vessels to distant sites.
  • Explains distant endometriosis, such as in the lungs, brain, or umbilicus.

Induction Theory

  • Suggests that biochemical or hormonal factors in the peritoneal cavity induce undifferentiated mesenchymal cells to differentiate into endometrial tissue.
  • Seen as a modification of the metaplasia theory, with unknown inducing signals.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman came to opd with a complaint of deep pelvic pain and infertility. The best investigation to establish the diagnosis of endometriosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis.

Typical lesion: Powder burn/Gunshot lesions (black, dark brown, or bluish cysts with old haemorrhage surrounded by variable degree of fibrosis)

Other non-typical findings could be:

  • Red implants
  • Serous or clear vesicles
  • White plaques/scarring
  • Yellowish brown discolouration of the peritoneum
  • Sub-ovarian adhesions
  • The presence of defects in the peritoneum (usually scarring overlying implants) is called Allen masters syndrome.
  • Histological confirmation of laparoscopic impression is essential for the diagnosis of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old lady has not had her menses for the last 4 months. She has high serum FSH and LH levels with low estradiol. The likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Premature menopause is defined as secondary amenorrhea before 40 years of age, due to ovarian failure. It is clinically defined as secondary amenorrhea for at least 3 months with raised FSH, raised FSH/LH ratio and low estrogen levels in women under 40 years of age.

Explanation for other options:

  • Exogenous oestrogen reduces FSH and LH by its feedback mechanism. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

For diagnosis of premature ovarian failure, serum FSH levels should be > 40 mIU/ml on 2 occasions, at least 1 month apart.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, para 2+0, with hypertension, has menorrhagia. Which is the best treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mirena is the best choice for this patient.

Why Mirena?

  • Effectively reduces menstrual blood loss.
  • Avoids estrogen, which is contraindicated in hypertension.
  • Minimally invasive, fertility-sparing.
  • Can be used for several years

The LNG IUS can be used in all women as a first line of treatment for menorrhagia in place of oral medications. It is particularly useful in reproductive-aged women who desire contraception.

Explanation for other options:

Hysterectomy (Option C): The female in this case is young, so we should not choose hysterectomy or endometrial ablation as the management of choice because in future she might desire pregnancy.

Combined pills (Option A): The Patient is hypertensive, hence OCPs are contraindicated.

TCRE (Option D): Requires anaesthesia and is usually reserved for failed medical management or when Mirena is not suitable.

questions.text: The commonest cause of post-menopausal bleeding in India is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common cancer causing postmenopausal bleeding in India and many developing countries is Ca Cervix, due to

  • Limited screening
  • Delayed diagnosis
  • Higher prevalence of HPV infection

Explanation for other options:

Ca endometrium (Option A): Common in obese, hypertensive, diabetic women, the most common cancer causing postmenopausal bleeding worldwide is Ca endometrium.

Ca vulva (Option C): Rare and usually causes local symptoms like itching or a mass, not common PMB.

Ovarian tumour (Option D): Typically presents with abdominal symptoms, not bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of poly-menorrhoea for the last six months. The first line of management is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  Dilatation and curettage is the first line of management in this case.

AUB Evaluation in Premenopausal Women (>40 years)

Initial Investigations:

  • Cervical cytology (Pap smear)
  • Ultrasound (endometrial thickness)
  • Sonohysterography (endometrial pathology)
  • Hysteroscopy with endometrial biopsy
  • Endometrial sampling / D&C
  • Laparoscopy (if needed)

If Malignancy Excluded: Based on Endometrial Histology,

questions.text: Puberty menorrhagia is treated by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Puberty menorrhagia is not treated by danazol due to its androgenic side effects (e.g. weight gain, acne, voice changes) and adverse effects on bone growth.

  • Puberty menorrhagiais excessive cyclical regular bleeding occurring in adolescents.
  • Most of the adolescent females have irregular periods for a variable period following menarche due to anovulatory cycles.
  • Anovulatory bleeding can be too frequent, prolonged or heavy, particularly after a long interval of amenorrhea.

Remember

In DUB, progesterone of choice:

  • For acute bleeding-Norethisterone
  • For maintenance purpose-DMPA
  • In patients with von Willebrand's disease, Desmopressin is the DOC
  • In young sexually active females, Levonorgestrel IUD- Mirena can also be used.

questions.text: Causes of dysfunctional uterine bleeding can be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Irregular ripening of the endometrium is one of the causes for dysfunctional uterine bleeding.

DUB is defined as a state of abnormal uterine bleeding without any clinically detectable organic pelvic pathology.

DUB is of 2 types:

  1. Anovulatory (80%)
  2. Ovulatory (20%)

Anovulatory (80%):

  • Threshold bleeding of puberty, menorrhagia
  • Metropathia haemorrhagica cystic glandular hyperplasia
  • Premenopausal DUB (Atrophy of endometrium).

Ovulatory (20%):

  • Irregular ripening of the corpus luteum
  • Irregular sheddingof the corpus luteum
  • IUD insertion
  • Following the sterilisation operation.

Explanation for other options:

Uterine polyp (Option A): It is a structural lesion (organic cause)

Fibroid (Option B): It is a benign tumour of the uterus (structural cause)

Granulosa cell tumour (Option C): It is a hormone-secreting tumour (estrogen → endometrial hyperplasia)

questions.text: Treatment of DUB in a young female is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hormones are the treatment of choice used to regulate cycles in young females.

  • Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding (DUB) in a young female is most commonly anovulatory and results from hormonal imbalance. The goal of treatment is to regulate the menstrual cycle, stop bleeding, and preserve fertility.

Medical Therapy.


Surgical therapy:

  • It is reserved for situations in which medical therapy has been unsuccessful or is contraindicated.
  • Surgical treatment depends on the cause of bleeding.

Explanation for other options:

Radiotherapy (Option B): Used for malignancy (e.g., endometrial or cervical cancer) and not used for DUB.

D & C (Option C): Rarely used as a diagnostic tool or for acute heavy bleeding if unresponsive to medical therapy.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Definitive but not suitable for young females wanting fertility.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presenting with dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia most probably has:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 45-year-old woman presenting with both dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia is most suggestive of endometriosis.

  • A combination of cyclic pelvic pain (dysmenorrhea) and heavy bleeding (menorrhagia) in a reproductive-age woman suggests endometriosis or adenomyosis (both often coexist or present similarly).

Explanation for other options:

DUB (Option A):

  • Typically, painless abnormal bleeding, not commonly associated with dysmenorrhea.
  • Bleeding is always painless and acyclical and continues for 2 - 8 days.
  • In about half the cases, it is preceded by a short period of amenorrhea (metropathia hemorrhagica).

Polyp (Option C):

  • Usually causes intermenstrual spotting or postcoital bleeding, not classically associated with pain.

Endometrial carcinoma (Option D):

  • Endometrial Ca is common in 55 - 60 years
  • Usually presents with postmenopausal bleeding, not with dysmenorrhea; more common after menopause.
  • The lower abdominal pain in the advanced stage is due to parametrial involvement.(Not dysmenorrhea)

questions.text: Treatment for a 33-year-old multipara with dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB) is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  The patient is 32 years old and is multiparous, so LNG-IUD will be the best option.

  • First-line medical therapy for DUB is progesterone.
  • Helps regulate endometrial growth and establish regular cycles.

Explanation for other options:

Danazol (Option B): It should not be used in young females, as it leads to androgenic side effects

Hysterectomy (Option D): It should not be done at 32 years unless and until definitive.

Prostaglandins (Option D): These are not used for managing DUB; rather, prostaglandin synthetase inhibitors are used.

choices.text: Carcinoma in situ of the cervix

questions.text: All are causes of postmenopausal bleeding except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carcinoma cervix in situ is not invasive and hence it won't cause postmenopausal bleeding.

Tumours of the reproductive tract causing postmenopausal bleeding:

  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Endometrial polyps
  • Endometrial cancer (the most common cancer causing postmenopausal bleeding worldwide) (Option B)
  • Cervical cancer (the most common cancer causing postmenopausal bleeding in India)
  • Uterine sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube carcinoma (Option D)
  • Ovarian CA - especially estrogen-secreting tumour (Option C)

questions.text: A woman of 50 years who attained menopause, coming with one episode of bleeding P/V. All of the following are to be done except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a 50-year-old postmenopausal woman with a single episode of vaginal bleeding, the workup should focus on ruling out malignancy and other endometrial pathology.

  • Hysterosalpingography is used to evaluate tubal patency in infertility work-ups and has no role in postmenopausal bleeding assessment.

Postmenopausal bleeding is more likely to be caused by pathological disease than is bleeding in younger women and must always be investigated.

Most common causes

  • Endometrial and vaginal atrophywhich are diagnosed by clinical examination.
  • The use of exogenous hormones, e. HRT (hormone replacement therapy). So, the history of the use of HRT becomes vital.
  • Tumours of the reproductive tract.

The investigations done to rule out tumours of the reproductive tract causing postmenopausal bleeding are:

  • Pap smear
  • Transvaginal sonography
  • Hysteroscopyand biopsy
  • Endometrial aspiration/biopsy
  • Dilatation and curettage

questions.text: Cryptomenorrhea occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An imperforate hymen is one of the causes of cryptomenorrhea

  • Cryptomenorrhea is a condition where menstrual blood is produced but cannot escape due to obstruction of the outflow tract. This results in cyclic abdominal pain and absence of visible menstruation, despite a functioning endometrium.

Explanation for other options:

Asherman's syndrome (Option B): Scarred/obliterated endometrial cavity with hypomenorrhea.

Mullerian agenesis (Option C): Congenital absence of uterus/endometrium with no menstruation-related symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clomiphene is used for ovulation induction in infertility; not indicated for bleeding control.

Medical Management of Menorrhagia:


NSAIDs

  • Rationale: Its use stems from the suspected role of prostaglandins in the pathogenesis of DUB.
  • Advantages: It is required only during menstruation and provides relief from dysmenorrhea
  • Tranexamic acid: It is an antifibrinolytic drug that exerts its effects by reversibly blocking lysine binding sites on plasminogen. The resulting decreased plasmin levels diminish fibrinolytic activity within endometrial vessels to prevent bleeding.

questions.text: Anita, a 14-year-old, complains of heavy periods for 2 months. On examination, her weight was 40 kg and BP: 120/80 mmHg. All of the following investigations are indicated, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Estradiol levels are not routinely required in the initial workup. Estradiol fluctuates in adolescents and does not provide actionable information in the early evaluation of puberty menorrhagia.

In a young adolescent like Anita presenting with puberty menorrhagia, common causes include anovulatory cycles due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, coagulopathies, endocrinological causes, etc.

Indicated Investigations:

  • Serum TSH - To rule out hypothyroidism. (Option A)
  • Platelet count - To check for thrombocytopenia (common in adolescents). (Option B)
  • Bleeding and clotting time - To assess primary hemostasis and coagulation disorders like Von Willebrand disease. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Always rule out a bleeding disorder in patients of puberty menorrhagia.

questions.text: Period of amenorrhea followed by massive bleeding is seen in premenopausal women with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metropathia Hemorrhagica is a classical anovulatory bleeding pattern. Unopposed estrogen causes cystic glandular hyperplasia of the endometrium, which results in amenorrhea followed by sudden, profuse bleeding.

  • It is a specialised form of DUB.
  • Mostly seen in premenopausal women.
  • Maximum age incidence:Between the ages of 40-45 years.

Pathology

  • The basic fault lies in the ovaries.
  • A slow increase in estrogen secretion occurs,
    But there is no negative feedback inhibition of FSH.
  • Leads to a gradual and prolonged rise in estrogen levels.

Effects of prolonged estrogen rise:

  • Initially Amenorrhea
  • Anovulation
    • No progestational support to the endometrium
    • The proliferated endometrium becomes weak
    • Eventually, it sheds completely

Result:

  • Heavy bleeding
  • Prolonged duration of bleeding

Changes in the Uterus:Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus to a size of 8 - 10 weeks due to hypertrophy of muscles.

Microscopic appearance:

  • Hyperplasia of all endometrial components.
  • Causes the appearance of "Swiss cheese".
  • Follicular cysts containing estrogen are present on the ovaries.
  • Secretory changes are absent. (No corkscrew glands seen)

Signs and Symptoms:Prolonged amenorrhea (of 6-8 weeks) followed by excessive painless bleeding (anovulatory bleeding).

Explanation for other options:

Irregular Ripening (Option A): It is due to deficient corpus luteum function. Inadequate progesterone causes delayed or incomplete secretory changes, which leads to prolonged estrogen stimulation followed by bleeding. No significant amenorrhea at the beginning.

Irregular Shedding (Option B): It is caused by a persistent corpus luteum, resulting in prolonged progesterone secretion. Bleeding occurs after progesterone withdrawal. Menstrual bleeding is prolonged or irregular.

questions.text: The investigation of choice in 55-year-old post- menopausal women who have presented with postmenopausal bleeding is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fractional curettage is the investigation of choice in 55-year-old post-menopausal women with postmenopausal bleeding.

  • Postmenopausal bleeding can occur due to Ca endometrium or Ca cervix.
  • Hence, in case of postmenopausal bleeding, ruling out both endometrial and cervical cancer is always a priority.
  • TVS can detect uterine pathology, but histopathological diagnosis is a must in such cases.(Option C)
  • PAP is positive only in 30-50% of Ca endometrium and so is not useful. (Option A)
  • TVS and CA-125 are screening methods for ovarian CA and hence not applicable here. (Option D)

questions.text: Metropathica hemorrhagica is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a type of anovulatory DUB; hence, it should be best treated by progesterone therapy for long-term regulation.

  • They diminish the effects of estrogen on target cells by inhibiting oestrogen receptors.
  • Metropathia hemorrhagica is mostly seen in premenopausal women.
  • Patients complain of a variable period of amenorrhea followed by excessive painless bleeding.
  • In HPE-cystic glandular hyperplasia, the Swiss cheese pattern is seen, and secretory changes are absent.

Explanation for other options:

Curettage of the uterus (Option A): Used for immediate control of bleeding, no role in long-term regulation.

Estrogen (Option C): It can worsen the condition by further stimulating the endometrium

Clomiphene (Option D): It is used for ovulation induction, not for treating active bleeding.
